TIPS

Some ideas you can use to be a more effective
Town or Community Councillor

You are not expected to do all of these.
This is just a list of some suggestions you may wish to
consider.
Although there is talk of some election strategy here it
is mainly intended for Town and Community Councillors
who currently hold a seat and wish to keep it.

Does a local organisation need someone to officially open or launch an event?

Does your branch publish regular newsletters? Make sure that it gives you high

Get to know your local press and radio reporters.

Get to know your community.

Get yourself elected as your Council’s representative on influential local groups.
Issue regular press releases

Send letters to the press.

Make sure you have a picture and a press release of the event. (as you have
obviously done with point 20)

Get high quality photos of yourself. Give or email a good copy to the local press
to use when you send your press releases in and remind them they have it.

Use your mobile phone, iPad or a digital camera and take a snap every time you
do something in public. Use the pictures.

Browse your other local political parties’ websites. What are they doing?

Get there first.

Become a school governor

Recruit members and supporters to your Plaid Branch

. Keep in constant contact with your local branch.

. If you don't have one attend the nearest one, and then after a while, when you've

collected local members, set up your own branch.

3. Use them as extra pairs of eyes and ears to gather local information.

. Use them to help you distribute leaflets.

9. If you belong to a branch and attend regularly propose yourself as a delegate to

Constituency committee, National Council etc.

. Attend National Council (two meetings a year) and get to learn more about your

Party's beliefs and policies, and to network with other colleagues in a similar
situation.

. Attend your Constituency Committee and /or your County Committee.

. Attend Plaid's conferences when they are within easy reach ( both the spring and

autumn National Conferences move around)

. You are welcome to attend Plaid Cymru's Councillor Association. It meets ar-

ound four times a year and welcomes representation from every Plaid Counc-
illor.

. Get to know what your limitations are — what you can and can not achieve as a

local Councillor.

. Find out who to pass on problems you can not tackle. If you have a local Plaid

illor in your authority, if you have one. Make friends with them so that they will

Browse your own council's website.
Browse your County Council's website.

Do you have a constituency office? Use it; get to know the staff and how they
can help you and how you can be of help to them.

If not then where is your nearest office? Where is your Regional AM's office?
Use it.

Work with local MSs, MPs, Actual or Candidates

Every time there is another election e.g. Westminster get yourself on the cam-
paign team when they visit your ward. Go round knocking doors with them,
introduce yourself as their local councillor — raise your profile. It looks so good
when you canvass in a gang.

All of Wales has at least one Plaid Regional Senedd member by now.

41. Ask for help — you will need all the help that you can get at election time.

42. Sponsor a Rugby / Football match

43. Organise petitions for worthwhile ventures.

44. Organise write in campaigns

45. Organise advice surgeries, or if you have a local County Councillor join forces.
46. Organise street surgeries

47. Organise residents’ surveys

48. Target 1° time voters

49. Do they receive an 18" birthday card from Plaid? If not send deliver one.
50. Get involved in Community Audits

51. Get yourself a mentor. Someone with political experience.

52. Draft yourself a letterhead

53. Decide on a clear corporate style

54. Make yourself a “sorry you were out when | called” card

55. Remember to vote leaflet

56. Deliver a Calendar or a card of useful/vital local services

57. Do you have a supply of posters and car stickers to sell to those who ask?
58. Have you got a Plaid car sticker on your car?

59.Keep literature design simple

60. Keep to Arial or a similar San Serif style of print

61. Remember that a print size under 10 is difficult to read.

62. Remember that white print on a black background or the use of colour is di-
fficult for those with sight problems.

63. Election address - keep your manifesto simple
64. Capitalise on a community issue

65. Put all constituents’ complaints to your Council or to any other body in writing
and keep your email trail.

66. Set up a ward web page.
67. Update it frequently, at least once a week, preferably oftener.

68. Put all local events on it to attract a regular readership.

97. Persuade them to stand. You never know when there will be a by-election in your or a |

98. A good councillor never says No without explaining why.

99. A good councillor never says ‘Yes’; instead, he or she will say ‘I will try

my best’.
100 If anyone asks if they owe you anything —say yes a vote for me and for

Plaid Cymru in every election that's all.
